civil_sections.summary: but if it appears to the court at the hearing of the petition that the petitioner obtained leave to present the petition by any misrepresentation or concealment of the nature of the case, the court may, if it pronounces a decree, do so subject to the condition that the decree shall not have effect until after the expiry of one year from the date of the marriage or may dismiss the petition without prejudice to any petition which may be brought after expiration of the said one year upon the same or substantially the same facts as those alleged in support of the petition so dismissed.

civil_sections.title: Divorced persons when may marry again
civil_sections.summary: When a marriage has been dissolved by a decree of divorce and either there is no right of appeal against the decree or, if there is such a right of appeal, the time for appealing has expired without an appeal having been presented, or an appeal has been presented but has been dismissed, it shall be lawful for either party to the marriage to marry again.

civil_sections.title: Legitimacy of children of void and voidable marriages
civil_sections.summary: Notwithstanding that marriage is null and void under section 11, any child of such marriage who would have been legitimate if the marriage had been valid, shall be legitimate, whether such child is born before or after the commencement of the Marriage Laws (Amendment) Act, 1976 (68 of 1976), and whether or not a decree of nullity is granted in respect of that marriage under this Act and whether or not the marriage is held to be void otherwise than on a petition under this Act.

civil_sections.title: Punishment of bigamy
civil_sections.summary: Any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of this Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living; and the provisions of sections 494 and 495 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (45 of 1860), shall apply accordingly.

civil_sections.title: Punishment for contravention of certain other conditions for a Hindu marriage
civil_sections.summary: Every person who procures a marriage of himself or herself to be solemnized under this Act in contravention of the conditions specified in clauses (iii), (iv),and (v) of section 5 shall be punishable—

civil_sections.summary: Every petition under this Act shall be presented to the district court within the local limits of whose ordinary original civil jurisdiction -

civil_sections.title: Contents and verification of petitions
civil_sections.summary: Every petition presented under this Act shall state as distinctly as the nature of the case permits the facts on which the claim to relief is founded and, except in a petition under section 11, shall also state that there is no collusion between the petitioner and the other party to the marriage.

civil_sections.title: Application of Act 5 of 1908
civil_sections.summary: Subject to the other provisions contained in this Act and to such rules as the High Court may make in this behalf, all proceedings under this Act shall be regulated, as far as may be, by the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

civil_sections.title: Power to transfer petitions in certain cases
civil_sections.summary: Where-

civil_sections.title: Special provision relating to trial and disposal of petitions under the Act
civil_sections.summary: The trial of a petition under this Act shall, so far as is practicable consistently with the interests of justice in respect of the trial, be continued from day to day until its conclusion unless the court finds the adjournment of the trial beyond the following day to be necessary for reasons to be recorded.

civil_sections.title: Documentary evidence
civil_sections.summary: Notwithstanding anything in any enactment to the contrary, no document shall be inadmissible in evidence in any proceeding at the trial of a petition under this Act on the ground that it is not duly stamped or registered.

civil_sections.title: Proceedings to be in camera and may not be printed or published
civil_sections.summary: Every proceeding under this Act shall be conducted in camera and it shall not be lawful for any person to print or publish any matter in relation to any such proceeding except a judgment of the High Court or of the Supreme Court printed or published with the previous permission of the court.

civil_sections.title: Relief for respondent in divorce and other proceedings
civil_sections.summary: In any proceeding for divorce or judicial separation or restitution of conjugal rights, the respondent may not only oppose the relief sought on the ground of petitioner’s adultery, cruelty or desertion, but also make a counter-claim for any relief under this Act on that ground; and if the petitioner’s adultery, cruelty or desertion is proved, the court may give to the respondent any relief under this Act to which he or she would have been entitled if he or she had presented a petition seeking such relief on that ground.

civil_sections.title: Maintenance pendente lite and expenses of proceedings
civil_sections.summary: Where in any proceeding under this Act it appears to the court that either the wife or the husband, as the case may be, has no independent income sufficient for her or his support and the necessary expenses of the proceeding, it may, on the application of the wife or the husband, order the respondent to pay to the petitioner the expenses of the proceeding, and monthly during the proceeding such sum as, having regard to the petitioner’s own income and the income of the respondent, it may seem to the court to be reasonable.

civil_sections.title: Permanent alimony and maintenance
civil_sections.summary: Any court exercising jurisdiction under this Act may, at the time of passing any decree or at any time subsequent thereto, on application made to it for the purpose by either the wife or the husband, as the case may be, order that the respondent shall pay to the applicant for her or his maintenance and support such gross sum or such monthly or periodical sum for a term not exceeding the life of the applicant as, having regard to the respondent’s own income and other property, if any, the income and other property of the applicant, the conduct of the parties and other circumstances of the case, it may seem to the court to be just, and any such payment may be secured, if necessary, by a charge on the immovable property of the respondent.

civil_sections.title: Custody of children
civil_sections.summary: In any proceeding under this Act, the court may, from time to time, pass such interim orders and make such provisions in the decree as it may deem just and proper with respect to the custody, maintenance and education of minor children, consistently with their wishes, wherever possible, and may, after the decree, upon application by petition for the purpose, make from time to time, all such orders and provisions with respect to the custody, maintenance and education of such children as might have been made by such decree or interim orders in case the proceeding for obtaining such decree were still pending, and the court may also from time to time revoke, suspend or vary any such orders and provisions previously made;

civil_sections.section: pending the proceeding for obtaining such decree
civil_sections.title: shall
civil_sections.summary: as far as possible, be disposed of within sixty days from the date of service of notice on the respondent.
civil_sections.usage: Chapter Provided that the application with respect to the maintenance and education of the minor children

civil_sections.title: Disposal of property
civil_sections.summary: In any proceeding under this Act, the court may make such provisions in the decree as it deems just and proper with respect to any property presented, at or about the time of marriage, which may belong jointly to both the husband and the wife.

civil_sections.title: Appeals from decrees and orders
civil_sections.summary: All decrees made by the court in any proceeding under this Act shall, subject to the provisions of sub-section (3), be appealable as decrees of the court made in the exercise of its original civil jurisdiction, and every such appeal shall lie to the court to which appeals ordinarily lie from the decisions of the court given in the exercise of its original civil jurisdiction.

civil_sections.title: Enforcement of decrees and orders
civil_sections.summary: All decrees and orders made by the court in any proceeding under this Act shall be enforced in the like manner as the decrees and orders of the court made in the exercise of its original civil jurisdiction for the time being in forced.

civil_sections.title: Savings
civil_sections.summary: A marriage solemnized between Hindus before the commencement of this Act, which is otherwise valid, shall not be deemed to be invalid or even to have been invalid by reason only of the fact that the parties thereto belonged to the same gotra or pravara or belonged to different religions, castes or subdivisions of the same caste.

civil_sections.title: Repeals
civil_sections.summary: Rep. by the Repealing and Amending Act, 1960 (58 of 1960), section 2 and First Schedule.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Eastern Book Company vs. Navin J. Desai
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the reproduction of the plaintiff's book by the defendant was fair use under Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Delhi High Court held that the reproduction of the plaintiff's book by the defendant was not fair use under Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of fair use under Section 52 of the Copyright Act, 1957.

landmark_cases_extra.name: F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. vs. Cipla Ltd.
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the patent granted to the plaintiff for the drug 'ERLOTINIB' was valid. The defendant argued that the patent was not valid as it was not a new invention.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Delhi High Court held that the patent granted to the plaintiff for the drug 'ERLOTINIB' was valid as it was a new invention.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of patent validity.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Bikram Yoga Inc. vs. Yoga Guru
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the use of the plaintiff's yoga sequences by the defendant was an infringement of the plaintiff's copyright.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Delhi High Court held that the use of the plaintiff's yoga sequences by the defendant was not an infringement of the plaintiff's copyright as yoga sequences are not copyrightable.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of copyright infringement.

landmark_cases_extra.name: American Express Bank Ltd. vs. Priya Sharan
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the defendant had misappropriated the plaintiff's trade secrets. The defendant argued that the trade secrets were not protectable as they were not confidential.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Delhi High Court held that the defendant had misappropriated the plaintiff's trade secrets as they were confidential and protectable.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of trade secrets.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Novartis AG vs. Union of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the patent granted to the plaintiff for the drug 'Glivec' was valid. The defendant argued that the patent was not valid as it was not a new invention.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Supreme Court held that the patent granted to the plaintiff for the drug 'Glivec' was not valid as it was not a new invention.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of patent validity.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Taj Television Ltd. vs. Rajan Mandal
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The issue was whether the defendant had infringed the plaintiff's copyright in the television program 'TEN SPORTS'.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Delhi High Court held that the defendant had infringed the plaintiff's copyright in the television program 'TEN SPORTS'.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: The decision clarified the scope of copyright infringement.

landmark_cases_extra.name: K.S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of the Aadhaar scheme. The petitioners argued that the scheme violated the right to privacy. The court had to decide whether the right to privacy is a fundamental right.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The right to privacy is a fundamental right under the Constitution of India.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Established the right to privacy as a fundamental right in India.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of the Aadhaar Act, 2016. The petitioners argued that the Act violated the right to privacy. The court had to decide whether the Aadhaar Act is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Aadhaar Act is constitutional, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the constitutionality of the Aadhaar Act with certain restrictions.

landmark_cases_extra.name: State of Jammu & Kashmir vs Dr. Shah Faesal
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the abrogation of Article 370 of the Constitution. The petitioners argued that the abrogation was unconstitutional. The court had to decide whether the abrogation of Article 370 was valid.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The abrogation of Article 370 is valid, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the abrogation of Article 370 with certain restrictions.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Shayara Bano vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of triple talaq. The petitioners argued that triple talaq violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether triple talaq is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: Triple talaq is unconstitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Declared triple talaq as unconstitutional.
sections: Section 2 of the Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937

landmark_cases_extra.name: Navtej Singh Johar vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of Section 377 of the IPC. The petitioners argued that Section 377 violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether Section 377 is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: Section 377 is unconstitutional insofar as it criminalizes consensual sexual acts between adults.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Decriminalized consensual sexual acts between adults.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of the National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC) Act, 2014. The petitioners argued that the NJAC Act violated the independence of the judiciary. The court had to decide whether the NJAC Act is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The NJAC Act is unconstitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Struck down the NJAC Act.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Indian Young Lawyers Association vs State Of Kerala
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the restriction on the entry of women into the Sabarimala temple. The petitioners argued that the restriction violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether the restriction is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The restriction on the entry of women into the Sabarimala temple is unconstitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Allowed the entry of women into the Sabarimala temple.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Vivek Narayan Sharma vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the demonetisation of currency notes. The petitioners argued that the demonetisation was unconstitutional. The court had to decide whether the demonetisation is valid.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The demonetisation is valid, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the demonetisation with certain restrictions.
sections: Section 26(2) of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934

landmark_cases_extra.name: Association For Democratic Reforms vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the electoral bond scheme. The petitioners argued that the scheme violated the right to know the source of political funding. The court had to decide whether the scheme is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The electoral bond scheme is valid, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the electoral bond scheme with certain restrictions.
sections: Section 29C of the Representation of the People Act, 1951

landmark_cases_extra.name: Assam Sanmilita Mahasangha vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019. The petitioners argued that the Act violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether the Act is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act is valid, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the Citizenship (Amendment) Act with certain restrictions.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Janhit Abhiyan vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the 10% reservation for economically weaker sections (EWS) in public employment and education. The petitioners argued that the reservation violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether the reservation is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The 10% reservation for EWS is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the 10% reservation for EWS.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Bachan Singh vs State Of Punjab
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case dealt with the issue of death penalty. The court had to decide whether the death penalty is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The death penalty is constitutional, but with certain restrictions.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the death penalty with certain restrictions.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Anuradha Bhasin vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the internet shutdown in Jammu and Kashmir. The petitioners argued that the shutdown violated the right to freedom of speech and expression. The court had to decide whether the shutdown is valid.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The internet shutdown is valid, but with certain restrictions.
principles: Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the internet shutdown with certain restrictions.
sections: Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973

landmark_cases_extra.name: Sedition Law Challenge
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of the sedition law. The petitioners argued that the law violated the right to freedom of speech and expression. The court had to decide whether the law is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The sedition law is constitutional, but with certain restrictions.
principles: Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the sedition law with certain restrictions.
sections: Section 124A of the Indian Penal Code

landmark_cases_extra.name: K.T. Thomas vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case dealt with the issue of reservation in public employment. The petitioners argued that the reservation policy violated the right to equality. The court had to decide whether the reservation policy is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The reservation policy is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the reservation policy.

landmark_cases_extra.name: Common Cause vs Union Of India
landmark_cases_extra.facts: The case challenged the constitutionality of the NOTA (None of the Above) option in elections. The petitioners argued that the NOTA option violated the right to secrecy of ballot. The court had to decide whether the NOTA option is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.held: The NOTA option is constitutional.
landmark_cases_extra.impact: Upheld the NOTA option.

legal_maxims.application: No one condemned unheard. Both parties must get fair hearing.
legal_maxims.example_case: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978) 1 SCC 248

legal_maxims.meaning: No one is a judge in his own cause
legal_maxims.application: Justice should not only be done, but seen to be done.
legal_maxims.example_case: A.K. Kraipak v. Union of India (1969) 2 SCC 262

legal_maxims.meaning: Equity aids the vigilant, not the sleepy
legal_maxims.application: Equity will not assist a person who has been negligent in asserting their rights.
legal_maxims.example_case: Ram Coomar Coondoo v. Chunder Canto Mookerjee (1876) 3 IA 37

legal_maxims.application: Equity will not act where there is an adequate remedy at law.
legal_maxims.example_case: Rajah Moottoo Ramalinga Sethur v. Periya Dorasami (1885) 11 IA 62

legal_maxims.application: Crimes that are inherently wrong, such as murder or theft.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Maharashtra v. Mayer Hans George (2001) 4 SCC 149

legal_maxims.application: Crimes that are wrong only because they are prohibited by law, such as traffic offenses.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Gujarat v. Rameshchandra R. Rathod (2005) 2 SCC 693

legal_maxims.application: The injury is of a kind that would not have occurred without negligence.
legal_maxims.example_case: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Subhagwanti (1966) 1 SCR 876

legal_maxims.maxim: Cuius est solum, eius est usque ad coelum
legal_maxims.meaning: Whoever owns the soil, it is theirs up to the sky
legal_maxims.application: Property rights extend to the sky above and the earth below.
legal_maxims.example_case: B.R. Gupta v. Union of India (1989) 4 SCC 179

legal_maxims.maxim: Eius est periculum, cuius est dominium
legal_maxims.meaning: The risk lies with the owner
legal_maxims.application: The owner of a thing bears the risk of its loss or destruction.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar Pandurang Sangewe (2005) 4 SCC 551

legal_maxims.meaning: The expression of one thing is the exclusion of another
legal_maxims.application: When a statute lists specific things, it implies that other things are excluded.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Bombay v. Ali Muhammad (1960) 1 SCR 713

legal_maxims.meaning: It is known from its associates
legal_maxims.application: The meaning of a word can be determined by the words surrounding it.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of West Bengal v. Union of India (1963) 2 SCR 525

legal_maxims.meaning: Of the same kind or class
legal_maxims.application: When a statute lists specific things, it implies that other things of the same kind are included.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co. (1958) 1 SCR 560

legal_maxims.meaning: Where there is a right, there is a remedy
legal_maxims.application: For every right, there is a corresponding remedy.
legal_maxims.example_case: Raj Kumar Pandey v. Sarita Pandey (2014) 4 SCC 589

legal_maxims.meaning: An act of the court shall prejudice no one
legal_maxims.application: The court will not allow its own actions to harm a party.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Punjab v. Sodhi Sukhdev Singh (1991) 2 SCC 301

legal_maxims.application: Acting with honesty and integrity.
legal_maxims.example_case: Kesoram Industries & Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax (1992) 2 SCC 511

legal_maxims.application: The buyer is responsible for ensuring the quality of the goods.
legal_maxims.example_case: Basant Kumar v. Ram Chandra (2002) 2 SCC 104

legal_maxims.application: A person may suffer damage without any legal injury.
legal_maxims.example_case: Bhimaji v. Shriram (1955) 2 SCR 594

legal_maxims.application: When both parties are equally at fault, the court will not provide relief.
legal_maxims.example_case: Kamal Pushp Enterprises v. Dr. R.K. Gupta (2000) 4 SCC 630

legal_maxims.application: A judgment or action that is directed against a thing, rather than a person.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of U.P. v. M.K. Gupta (2004) 10 SCC 504

legal_maxims.application: A judgment or action that is directed against a person, rather than a thing.
legal_maxims.example_case: Kuldip Nayar v. Union of India (2006) 7 SCC 1

legal_maxims.application: The intention or knowledge of wrongdoing that is necessary for a crime to be committed.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Maharashtra v. Mayer Hans George (2001) 4 SCC 149

legal_maxims.application: A judgment that is given without proper consideration of the law or facts.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of U.P. v. Synthetics & Chemicals Ltd. (1991) 4 SCC 139

legal_maxims.application: Something that is considered in isolation, without reference to other factors.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar Pandurang Sangewe (2005) 4 SCC 551

legal_maxims.application: A case that appears strong at first glance, but may not be so upon closer examination.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of U.P. v. Ravindra Kumar (2005) 12 SCC 133

legal_maxims.application: The underlying principle or reasoning that leads to a judicial decision.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of West Bengal v. Union of India (1963) 2 SCR 525

legal_maxims.application: A matter that has already been decided by a court and cannot be litigated again.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of U.P. v. Nawab Hussain (1977) 2 SCC 806

legal_maxims.application: A matter that is currently being considered by a court and has not yet been decided.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Maharashtra v. Mayer Hans George (2001) 4 SCC 149

legal_maxims.application: Something that is unique or one-of-a-kind.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of U.P. v. Synthetics & Chemicals Ltd. (1991) 4 SCC 139

legal_maxims.application: Land that is not owned by anyone, and is therefore open to occupation or settlement.
legal_maxims.example_case: State of Madras v. Pyaralia M.A. (1966) 1 SCR 334

legal_maxims.meaning: No injury is done to a willing person
legal_maxims.application: A person who consents to a risk or activity cannot later claim injury or damages.
legal_maxims.example_case: Bhimaji v. Shriram (1955) 2 SCR 594
